body.p: This topic is of special interest in case you are creating a CSS stylesheet for a custom XML document. For HTML already defines the needed selectors for the table element.
Let's consider a table in an XML document:
body.codeblock: <tbl> <caption>A table.</caption> <rw> <c rspan="2"> Spans vertically </c> <c> Other cell </c> <c> Other cell </c> </rw> <rw> <c cspan="2"> Other cell, spanning to the right </c> </rw> </tbl>

section.title: Defining the Column and Row Span
section.p: The processor needs to know how the cells are spanning multiple rows or columns. For these, there are available two properties: table-column-span and table-row-span.

section.title: Repeating Headers and Footers
section.p: The elements marked with one of the properties: table-header-group or table-footer-group are automatically repeated when a table is split over a sequence of pages. It is required that they contain only elements with the display table-row.

section.title: Rotating tables
section.p: There are cases in which you have large tables, and you need to rotate them to make them fit on your page. For instance the default page is portrait, but because you have a table with many columns, and thus very wide, it would bleed to the right of the page.
